questions.text:
Which of the following investigations can be used in osteoporosis?
1. DEXA
2. Bone scan
3. Quantitative CT
4. Chemical analysis
Select the answer using following key-
questions.solution:
Osteoporosis is a generalised reduction in the bone mineralization and leads to weak bones. Various imaging modalities are used in osteoporosis detection. Among the given options, DEXA, Quantitative CT and Chemical analysis is used.

Bone scan is a nuclear medicine technique and is not used in osteoporosis assessment.

KEY TAKEAWAY- The following modalities are used for detection of osteoporosis:

Reference: AIIMS-MAMC-PGl's Comprehensive textbook of diagnostic radiology page 2888

questions.text: In E-FAST, which if the following part of the body is included apart from the abdomen?
questions.solution:
Views for E-FAST

KEY TAKEAWAY- Ultrasound is now routinely used to detect pneumothorax in emergency settings. Standard lung views are now part of E-Fast ultrasound (Extended - focussed assessment with Sonography in trauma). Ultrasound has higher sensitivity than chest radiograph in the diagnosis of pneumothorax, especially in identifying occult pneumothoraces of traumatic origin.

Reference: AIIMS-MAMC-PGl's Comprehensive textbook of diagnostic radiology page 2532

questions.text: On 5 postoperative day following Lap cholecystectomy, A patient presented with pain in the abdomen, On USG, A 5 x 5 cm collection is seen in the Morrison's pouch. A possibility of biliary leak is suspected. What is the most sensitive investigation to detect?
questions.solution:
For biliary leak we take a biliary excreting agent. HIDA is a biliary specific agent which is excreted in bile and is used for biliary leak.It is most sensitive but gives poor anatomical details

Option A -ERCP- it is both diagnostic and therapeutic and is most accurate for detecting anatomical site of leak. Poor anatomical details.

Option C -MR Cholangiography with hepatobiliary contrast is useful. Alone MRCP is not used.

Option D -CECT(Contrast-Enhanced CT) may show collections, but it is not the best test for detecting active bile leakage.

Reference: AIIMS-MAMC-PGl's Comprehensive textbook of diagnostic radiology page 861

questions.text: A young patient with intermittent pain in the calf is presented to surgery OPD. On examination, a painful ulcer is seen at the tip of great toe surrounded by black colour skin. Best initial investigation in this case would be-
questions.solution:
It is a case of buerger disease [nonatheroscleroticcondition ]. The best initial investigation in this patient who appears to have a Peripheral Vascular Disease (PVD) is a Doppler ultrasound which shows poor perfusion of major vessels and corkscrew collaterals.

The most common cause of PAD is atherosclerosis, the buildup of plaque inside the artery wall. DSA, which is considered to be gold standard gives information regarding the luminal patency and the presence of collaterals thus this patient who has an ulcer benefits from DSA with diagnosis prompting the required treatment.

KEY TAKEAWAY- Buerger disease, Thromboangiitis obliterans:

Characteristic angiographic findings:

  • Corkscrew collateral vessels
  • Bilateral Small and medium sized vessels, mainly of lower limbs involved with Sparing of the larger inflow vessels
  • Smooth intimal lining
  • No calcification

Reference: AIIMS-MAMC-PGl's Comprehensive textbook of diagnostic radiology page 3342

questions.text: A 7 year old child presented with lymphadenopathy, skin lesion and following skull radiograph. Which if the following drug is commonly used in this scenario?
questions.solution:
Langerhans cell histiocytosis (LCH), often referred to as eosinophilic granuloma (EG) is a rare multisystem disease with a wide and heterogeneous clinical spectrum and variable extent of involvement.

The radiographic features involving the skull are

  • solitary or multiple punched out lytic lesions without sclerotic rim
  • double contour or beveled edge appearance may be seen due to asymmetrical involvement of the inner and outer tables (hole within a hole) sign 7
  • button sequestrum representing residual bone
  • geographic skull

The management of such cases is by using Vincristine.

Reference: AIIMS-MAMC-PGl's Comprehensive textbook of diagnostic radiology page no 1030

questions.text: A 40-year-old patient with a history of peptic ulcer disease was having abdominal pain for many days. It gets worse since last two hours. A radiograph was performed and shown here. What is to be done in this patient?
questions.solution:
The given image shows free air under the right dome of diaphragm which is suggestive of enteric perforation. Management in such patients is stabilization of the patient by IV fluid and emergency laparotomy to search for the cause.

Reference: AIIMS-MAMC-PGl's Comprehensive textbook of diagnostic radiology page no 2080

questions.text: A 30-year-old patient with progressive difficulty in swallowing both solids and liquids for 8 months. Ba swallow was done and shown below. What other investigations should be done in this patient?
questions.solution:
Achalasia is an uncommon motility disorder of the esophagus characterized by a loss of primary esophageal peristalsis, incomplete relaxation of the lower esophageal sphincter in response to deglutition, increased resting LES pressure, and increased intraesophageal pressure. Barium swallow with the patient erect demonstrates a variable degree of dilatation of the esophagus above a beak-like narrowing at the lower esophageal sphincter.. A gradual, tapered, smooth, conical narrowing of the distal esophageal segment extending for 1-3 cm in length is known as bird's beak appearance and is the hallmark of achalasia.

  • The given image shows a Bird beak appearance on Barium swallow suggestive of Achalasia cardia.
  • The gold standard investigation is Manometry
  • Upper GI Endoscopy looks for any masses and causes.

Reference: AIIMS-MAMC-PGI'S Comprehensive textbook of diagnostic radiology page no 2407

questions.text: A young male met with an RTA and was brought to casualty with GCS score as e2v2m3. He has raised ICT. No significant changes were seen on NCCT. The spinal imaging was also normal. What could be the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
DAI is also known as traumatic axonal stretch injury. DAI typically causes much more significant impairment compared with extracerebral hematomas and cortical contusions.

DAI often causes immediate loss of consciousness, which may be transient (in the case of mild TBI) or progress to coma. CT scans in such patients may be normal. As most DAls are nonhemorrhagic, T1 scans are often normal, especially in the early stages of TBI. T2WI and FLAIR may show hyperintense foci in the subcortical white matter and corpus callosum.

T2* scans are very sensitive to the microbleeds of DAI and typically show multifocal ovoid and linear hypointensities. DWI may show restricted diffusion, particularly within the corpus callosum. Whole-brain tractography(DTI) may be useful in depicting white matter disruption.

Reference: Osborn Brain edition 2 Brain edition 2 pg 45

choices.text: Immediately shift the patient to OT for thoracotomy
Put a Large bore needle in the 5nd lntercostal space and then ICD in 5th intercostal space

questions.text: A 25-year-old patient came to emergency after road traffic accident, he was able to speak but not in sentences. On Auscultation, a hyperesonant note is seen on the right side. Chest x-ray was given below. What is the most appropriate initial management of this patient?
questions.solution:
The given chest radiograph shows absent Bronchovascular marking and visceral pleural line and deep sulcus suggestive of right sided pneumothorax.

The most appropriate initial management would be placing a large bore needle (14 G) in the 5th Intercoastal space followed by Intercoastal drainage.

Reference: MacDuff A, Arnold A, Harvey J Management of spontaneous pneumothorax: British Thoracic Society pleural disease guideline 2010 Thorax 2010;65:ii18-ii31

questions.text: A 40-year-old male is suffering from increasing difficulty in bending forward with increasing stiffness of the spine. A Ct was performed and shown below. Likely Diagnosis-
questions.solution:
The given xray shows bamboo spine due to osteophyte formation which is suggestive of ankylosing spondylitis.

Ankylosing spondylitis is a chronic, progressive inflammatory arthritis which chiefly involves the synovial joints of the spine along with the adjacent soft tissues as well as the sacroiliac joints, although peripheral, large joints such as the hips, shoulders and knee can also be involved.

Radiological features:

SI joints: The classic sacroiliitis is bilateral and symmetrical. Changes occur in both the synovial along with ligamentous (superior and posterior) parts of the sacroiliac joints.

The earliest radiographic findings occur in the subchondral cortex which appears blurred or lost.
Later, small (rat-bite) erosions appear which are worse along the iliac aspect of the joint. These cause widening of the joint space with hazy margins. This is followed by larger erosions, subjacent sclerosis and joint space narrowing as irregular new bone bridges the joint space with eventual ankylosis and resolution of the sclerosis.

The modified New York criteria is used for grading of sacroiliitis and was established in 1994.

Spine: Spinal involvement classically starts at the dorsolumbar or lumbosacral junction.
Erosions initially occur at the vertebral margins at the site of attachment of the outer fibers of the annulus fibrosus (Romanus lesions) with adjacent sclerosis (shiny corner sign).

Healing of these erosions or laying down of bone beneath the anterior longitudinal ligament causes "squaring" of the vertebral bodies, best appreciated on lateral radiographs of the lumbar spine.
Exuberant new bone formation may even cause anterior convexity of the vertebral body (barrel-shaped vertebrae).

Ossifications may be seen in the interspinous ligaments and facet joints causing the dagger and tram-track signs respectively.
Facet joint ankylosis is the major factor causing loss of spinal mobility.

Dagger sign

Tram Track/Trolley sign

KEY TAKEAWAY- Radiological findings in Ankylosing Spondylitis.

Calcification of anterior longitudinal ligament.

Calcification of intervertebral disc giving rise to bamboo spine//Tram track sign/Trolley sign.

Calcification of interspinous ligament- dagger sign

On MRI -lesions seen in the anterior part of intervertebral disc [Andersson lesion ].

Reference: AIIMS-MAMC-PGI'S Comprehensive textbook of diagnostic radiology page no 2830

questions.text: A 40 year old male patient with mucopurulent cough underwent a CT examination. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Bronchiectasis is a chronic condition characterised by irre-versible dilatation of the bronchi, usually associated with inflammation which occur secondary to bronchial obstruction, bronchial wall damage or parenchymal fibrosis.

Bronchial dilatation is the most specific finding of bronchiectasis and is considered when the broncho arterial ratio exceeds one. When bronchial dilatation is marked, the cross section appearance of the bronchus and artery together appears as a ring and is termed as the "signet ring" sign.

Lack of bronchial tapering: This is the earliest sign of bronchiectasis and is easiest to detect when the bronchus is seen in longitudinal section.

Visualization of peripheral airway: Normal airways are not visualized within 1 cm of the costal pleura. If visualized, then are considered abnormal and indicative of bronchiectasis. Airways may be seen within 1 cm of mediastinal pleura, but should not abut the mediastinal pleura.

Mucoid impaction: Dilated bronchi when filled with fluid or mucous are easily appreciated on HRCT. They appear as gloved finger, V or Y shaped branching densities

Reference: AIIMS-MAMC-PGl's Comprehensive textbook of diagnostic radiology page 2307

questions.text: The radiograph shown below is done for better assessment of the frontal sinus. What is the common name of this view?
questions.solution:
The Caldwell view is a specific type of X-ray used to visualize the paranasal sinuses, especially the frontal sinus.

The Caldwell view is a caudally angled radiograph, with its posteroanterior projection allowing for minimal radiation to the orbits. This view may be used in imaging of the skull or facial bones depending on the clinical indications.


Water's View

Towne's View-Angulated AP view of skull with 30 degree angulation.

KEY TAKEAWAY-

caldwell view (occipito- frontal view)- for frontal sinus /superior orbital fissure

Water's view(occipito-Mental view)- Maxillary sinus

Rhese view (Lateral oblique)- ethmoid sinus/optic canal.

Pierre's View (occipito mental with open mouth)- sphenoid and maxillary sinus.

Base skull view(submentovertical view) - sphenoid sinus.

Reference: AIIMS-MAMC-PGI's Comprehensive textbook of diagnostic radiology page 3308
